bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George C. Kellogg, January 3, 1942

div1.p: Hench writes to Kellogg about acquiring a framed copy of the Cornwell painting for George Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George C. Kellogg, January 3, 1942
div1.p:
Will you help me in a deep, dyed plot? Nobody, including myself,
has been able to connect with George Carroll in Washington, Dr. Carroll's
son. For reasons known to himself but suspected by me, he is very elusive
and suspicious.

In the hope that he may not remember the saying “Beware of the
Greeks bearing gifts” I should like to suddenly appear at his door when I
land in Washington about ten days from now and have in my hand for him a
framed copy of the yellow fever picture. I don't believe you ever sent him
one as I don't believe you had his address. Perhaps if I have a smile on
my face and a Cornwell picture in my hand, he will let me get in and start
talking.

Mrs. Hench and I expect to spend several days in Washington after
a hasty trip to New York and then to the meeting of the American Academy of
Orthopedic Surgeons in Atlantic City, where I speak. We expect to land at
the Willard Hotel in Washington, D. C. on January 13. Would it be possible
for you to send to that address, to be hold for me, a framed copy and perhaps
an extra unframed copy of the yellow fever painting? I have no doubt that
you would want him to have one anyhow. I expect to see General Reed, Mrs.
Walter Reed and Blossom, also General Kean and others.
div1.closer:
Always sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. Mr. George Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
